headline: Russian Cabbage Borscht
description: Red cabbage and beets are slowly stewed with sauteed onions, caraway seeds, potatoes, carrots, celery, and dill weed. Cider vinegar, honey, and tomato puree provide additional depth of flavor to this recipe originally handed down from an elderly Turkish woman.
name: Russian Cabbage Borscht

recipeInstructions.text: Place sliced potatoes and beets in a medium saucepan over high heat; cover with stock, and boil until vegetables are tender. Remove potatoes and beets with a slotted spoon, and reserve stock.

Melt butter in a large skillet over medium heat. Stir in onions, caraway seeds, and salt; cook until onions become soft and translucent. Then stir in celery, carrots, and cabbage. Mix in reserved stock; cook, covered, until all vegetables are tender, about 10 minutes.

Add potatoes and beets to the skillet. Season with black pepper and dill weed. Stir in cider vinegar, honey, and tomato puree. Cover, reduce heat to medium low, and simmer at least 30 minutes. Serve topped with sour cream, extra dill weed, and chopped fresh tomatoes.

review.reviewBody: I added bay leaf and sliced beef, so delish!
At every step I needed a lot more water. I’m not sure what tomato purée is. So I used half a cup of tomato paste. It drowned out all the subtle flavors, so I ended up with spaghetti sauce.

Delicious! I left out the potatoes (didn't have any) and the caraway seeds ( just don't like them), and it was still really good! It may not be completely authentic but in the end, it was easy and delicious and reminded me of my grandparents... Thank you
I also added parsnips and turnips

This recipe is wonderful. It really needs little in the way of additions. I add celeriac as I do to all soups for a little extra flavour. I don't love store bought vegetable broth so add sacrificial veggies, long pieces of celery, carrot etc. I can fish out after long cooking. Fresh dill is a must. A dash of crushed chilis for a little kick.
My family love this borscht! I usually puree it when done because I seem to like my soups smooth.
I like it!

Delicious. Not my mother's borscht (she used to make it with meat) but loved it and I'm saving the recipe. I added a couple of bay leaves and 3 whole allspice. Instead of slicing the beets and potatoes I cut them into small cubes.
Very similar to the Moosewood Cookbook recipe
I made this exactly as the recipe described , using the caraway seeds. I really like it, but it is quite sweet - maybe too sweet for some.
Excellent, I used white cabbage because that’s all I had and added some fennel seeds and it was aromatic and just delicious!

Excellent. I used to eat borscht when I lived in Estonia, and this made me miss the black bread they would eat with their borscht. Consider adding wurst for meat eaters. The caraway seeds and dill are necessary in this soup. I used a can of beets instead.
I copied this recipe onto an index card and renamed it Best Borscht Ever! it involves fresh ingredients and is wonderful!
A bit too salty, but otherwise delicious!
This borscht is amazing - just the way I like it!I used red onions 8nstead of yellow as that's all I had! Canned O. tomatoes instead of tomato sauce. Perfect! Great for a cold winter's night!
I made a double batch of this for a cottage weekend and everyone loved it! I put in much more dill.

This was a sleeper recipe. I had my doubts as I assembled it. My husband LOVED it. Once the sour cream and a little salt hit the bowl, we were SOLD. 

It was delicious. We'll definitely be making this again!
Absolutely delicious! Wouldn't change a thing!
Very good, but added ginger and jalapeno pepper for more kick.
Very tasty comfort food. I like having it ready to go if i come home late. I serve it hot w a slice of rye bread.
This was my 1st time to try this recipe. My husband & I loved it! So good on a cold night! I had to use dried dill, but it still had a pretty good flavor. I followed the recipe.

My MIL has been raving about borscht she had years ago at Christmas since I met her. My husband had made his borscht once before and I was less than impressed. Disclaimer* that’s the only time I’ve ever had borscht. I also did not measure this exactly. That’s not how I cook, with the exception of baking. That said, this was absolutely delicious, once I seasoned with salt to my taste. (MIL has sodium restrictions.) A huge dollop of sour cream and this will absolutely be a routine dish in our house. I found my food processor to be invaluable. I shredded the cabbage and beets, then sliced the potatoes with it. I also cooked it in the instant pot.

Definitely use a food processor if you have one to cut the vegetables because it takes longer than 20 minutes to put this together if you don't! I love Borscht (I live in Russia most of the year) and I'm trying to go meatless. The flavor is still rich even without the meat!

I have only had Borscht once before and enjoyed it so I was happy to try this recipe as we have beets and purple cabbage growing in the garden. I had to substitute ketchup for the tomato puree so I will make sure to try puree and carroway the next time.

I added 2 more cups of veggie stock to make it more of a soup. Next time I will cut beets and potatoes into small, bite size cubes (slices are hard to eat). But the taste is fabulous. Having lived in Russia I think I can share that this is a wonderful, authentic recipe. So yummy!!!
My. 1st attempt was pretty good. I did a few modifications for convenience and pureed a cup. Excellent winter meal!

This borscht is the best I have ever made. I substitute leeks for the onion due to an allergy. Instead of tomato purée I used a large tin of tomatoes. To improve the consistency of the soup I used a hand blender and blended it a bit so the soup was creamier. I omitted the honey as the farm carrot was plenty sweet. It is a fantastic recipe that you can modify to accommodate what you have in your pantry. Do make this borscht--you will be glad you did.

It was very good but not as good as my friend that is from Azerbaijan makes. I'm pretty sure she adds beef. I omitted the caraway and added more cabbage and onion. It seems like its missing some spice but not sure if it needs more dill. I will be modifying next time or looking at other recipes to find what its missing.
Followed the recipe. I was not sure what I was in for, and I am excited to say this was absolutely delicious. I will definitely make this again!

So I was nervous to make this (despite the 5 star review) because I feared it wouldn't taste like the borscht my mom and (German-Russian) grandma made. Well I made it anyway and it is such a win! I even left out the potato and caraway seeds since I didn't have those things on hand and it still turned out just like I remember it. Thanks for a great recipe! :)

Very awesome. I used chicken broth instead and I added chicken sausage. I used pickled beets and red potatoes in order to reduce the time to cook; that allowed me to add the beet/potato mix into the skillet immediately following the end of step two. Oh and I didn't have any dill weed.
Turned out amazing! I doubled the recipe because I had so many fresh beets, carrots, potatoes, and dill from my garden and I'm so glad I did because I can't get enough of it!
The next time I will grate the beets, otherwise is was wonderful.
My husband is from the former Soviet Union and loves this recipe. I make it often.
So delicious! By far the best borscht I have ever had. Easy to make.
My husband loved it , better than his Ukrainian grandmother's
I usually don't eat beets, but this is a good way to eat it.
Our family of four ate this up in one sitting. Everybody went back for seconds or thirds!
Good, but ratio is a little off. I would do a lot more beets and less tomato purée: 4:1 ratio. I also use the small (28 oz) cans (4) of shredded beets bc I'm too lazy to cook the beets.

I followed the recipe and it is excellent. I was a bit unsure of the caraway seed, however it does add to the overall flavor of the soup. 
I agree with previous reviewers who wrote about the variety of borscht.whether or not one calls the recipe authentic May be based on the type your mother made!
I loved this recipe. only change I made was having to add an additional cup of water

Best. Borscht. Ever! I've tried many different borscht recipes, but this one is the most flavourful and delicious one yet! I changed up the method a little to simplify things. I started with sautéing the onions, celery and added 3 cloves of minced garlic (What? No garlic in borscht!? Unimaginable!) then added the broth, potatoes, carrots and doubled the amount of beets and let it cook for about 30 minutes. I then added the rest of the ingredients (maybe a bit more cabbage than called for) and let it simmer for about 30 minutes. I will add a little more liquid next time, as the soup turned out quite thick. Absolutely wonderful soup!

I have never eaten borscht before, so I can't speak to its authenticity, but this was an incredible bowl of soup! I have two picky kids, a pickier husband, and a roommate who doesn't like beets- We ALL loved it! Like, LOVED it! I modified the recipe slightly to fit what was in my fridge, but I mostly stayed true to the recipe. So, so, so good! And absolutely no leftovers (and I doubled the recipe).

Really enjoyed this recipe. Made a second pot this week with with my plentiful fresh ingredients! Three other tasters also gave it a thumbs up. As far as changes go I used pre shredded coleslaw mix ( mostly green) . Substituted white vinegar and dried dill. Omitted honey and caraway. Tasted like my Auntie Marie's. Thanks for the recipe.

Absolutely delicious, this will be one of my keeper soup recipes. The apple cider vinegar scared me a bit as I can't stand the smell and I find it off-putting in salad dressings, but I couldn't taste it. I used homemade chicken broth instead of veggie stock, and used a bit less salt and honey than called for, but it still sings with flavour. I left out the caraway. Mine turned out more pink than red as my beets were a lighter colour variety. I didn't have tomato purée but used 1/2 the amount of tomato paste instead. Lately, I tore up the beet greens and threw them in 15 minutes before the end of cooking time. It was perfect.
Didn't have red cabbage so used Napa instead. Tasted great!. Also no celery but didn't miss it.
This is absolutely delicious. I did not make any changes. OK, perhaps I had an extra deal and caraway seeds.

Oh my god, I don't care if it's not authentic. I wouldn't care if it was toxic waste, I've found my new favorite dish! It's amazing, very interestingly flavor and hearty. Only thing I noticed is next time I will increase some of the cooking times, my beets never really got tender, but they add a crunch.
Perfect! I think I'll try it with a little bit of beef next time to change it up! My family of 9 gives it a thumbs up :-)
Amazing recipe! Definitely add the caraway seed but half the amount.

Excellent! A truly brillant recipe. Served it to family and a bunch of friends with great success.

For those readers outside the USA, here the quantities in international units:

Potatoes and beets: 450g each.
Onions: 250g.
Carrots: 200g (a bit more than in the recipe). 
Celeri was not possible: used 170g leeks instead: very nice.
500g red cabbage.
1 liter stock (to be adjusted according to need).
Tomato purée: I used a 300ml jar of passata.
I'm not sure honey is necessary; I'll skip it next time.
Caraway seed: absolutely, and generously so! Just like the hacked chives on top of the cream. Lovely.
Great recipe. The borscht a Russian family I lived with (in Russia) tasted about the same.

I did not add the Caraway seeds, as I don't like them. And, the can of tomato puree I bought was 10.5 ounces, so I just added the whole can instead of wasting the last 2.5 ounces, or trying to keep it for something else.
This recipe made my husband (who doesn't like beets) ask how I got the beets to NOT taste like beets. 
It was fantastic, and my first attempt at making borscht - I will likely make it again.

This is a FANTASTIC recipe. I highly recommend making this borscht. We make it every year for Russian Christmas; it's quite the treat! You can put less apple cider vinegar in it if you don't want it to be so strong. I like it strong, but my children don't.
loved it! Must make again. Didn't have dillweed or celery seed or cider vinegar - used balsamic vinegar

This recipe makes an excellent non meat borscht. There are a lot of ingredients that give a depth of flavour. I do think the prep steps are overly complicated. In the end it all goes together to simmer in soup for a prolonged period, so I don't really think all the separate preps for different vegetables is really necessary. I didn't bother with using a stock, with all the strong vegetable flavours, water works perfectly fine. But this will be my go to borscht recipe.

It was absolutely delicious! 
My grandmother made borscht, but it was nothing like this, and frankly, as a child I never cared for it. I used chicken broth in this because that is what I had, and I did use the carraway seed. It was great with both and I would definitely make it again.
 To say that one recipe is authentic and others are not is like saying your chicken soup recipe is the only authentic chicken soup.

I've made it twice in the past month. I love this recipe, my husband doesn't like caraway seeds so I just omit them and it still turns out great. I like to quarter my beet slices so that they fit easier on the spoon. I forgot to get tomato puree the 2nd time and pureed whole canned tomatoes. I use online recipes all the time but this was the 1st one I had to rate.

This was spectacular! It will become one of my go to winter recipes. I substituted three ingredients: organic grass fed butter for Land O Lakes, organic full fat yogurt (White Mountain) for sour cream, and purple sweet potatoes for conventional white potatoes. Now I need to find a good source of authentic Russian rye bread to accompany this outstanding dish. Thanks, L J Hyde

I received some beautiful golden beets in my food co-op basket and decided to try my hand at Borscht. Tons of different recipes out there, people are vehement that theirs is THE best. Hmm. OK. This was to be my first, but I like it so much I will not make the others! 

I scrubbed and shredded all veggies, removed no skins. Shredding meant the pieces were all uniform, I finely chopped the onion and celery. My only substation was kale instead of cabbage. (I thought I had some, I was wrong!) O.M.G. this turned out great! With the golden beets, I have more of a yellow soup, but, as I said, it's wonderful! Definitely will make this one again!
I used purple potatoes and sauteed the other veggies in bacon fat. Oh My Goodness! So lovely. Thank you for this recipe.

My mother used to make Borscht all the time and I loved it... This recipe is so close to how she made it... Being home sick with pneumonia i needed something to to get me through the recovery process... and this hit the spot... The only things I changed were I used Beef Broth instead of vegetable broth.. and eliminated the dill and celery...
Such a delicious recipe, I have done it many times. I use cumin instead of caraway. Thanks!
It is so tasty. my husband is Russian and my mother in law always makes borscht, dare I say that this recipe is even better than hers! I put way more dill and threw in some lemon wedges yummy.
This is a more complex recipe than most, but the taste is the reward. I loved it!

This is magic!! This was my first time making borscht, and even my very non-Russian mother, who is very dubious about beets and carraway seeds, confessed that she loved it. This is now my go-to recipe for snowy winter evenings. I'm so excited.
Good recipe. Hearty and adaptable. The caraway and cider vinegar are nice.
This was absolutely delicious soup. I added tomato sauce instead of puree and it was fine. I doubled the recipe and it went very fast.
Soooo good! I had never made or even tried this soup before! Scrumptious!!

This turned out perfect! I followed the instructions without modification. It's a great combination of flavors that contributed to a pleasant, hearty soup. I also like that this recipe didn't call for heavy cream since the sour cream is enough. We will definitely make this version of borscht again and again!

A Russian friend has introduced me to her cooking and now I have a new foodie passion. This recipe is the first Russian/Ukraine food I've ever attempted, so I did not dare change a thing. And it was fabulous. I recently ate at a reputable Russian/Ukrainian restaurant in Chicago with this same Russian friend, and this borscht was far better than that which I paid $9/bowl for. I will likely add another 1-2 cups of stock to help it go a little further. And definitely serve it with a dollop of sour cream. (And thank you to the reviewer whom suggested using Trader Joe's precooked beets.I will try that next time.)
Best dish ever.
it's a perfectly fine recipe. i made it vegan (except for the honey) and it was tastey.
Just made this. This is delicious! Just like the one from Veselka in the East Village of NYC, where the Little Ukraine is located.

This is pretty much like the borscht I usually make except I use beef stock and diced canned tomatoes. Mine did not have the apple cider vinegar or honey which I tried this time. Imo this is a delicious borscht.

Been living in Russia for 10 years, and this was one of the best I've tried. There are several types of borsch - sweet or sour, tomato-ey or beet-ey. This is a beet-ey, sweet one which is just the type that I love. Tasted very authentic. I put in two medium sized beets (more than the recipe called for), and about 1.25L of broth (also more). I also added 350g of cubed beef. Simmered for about 4 hours. I would say it could about 4 people. 

No need to debate the merits of certain ingredients and whether they should or shouldn't be in a "real" borsch recipe. The end result is that this tastes exactly as borsch should.
Makes enough to feed an army.

Really delicious recipe! Full of umami, sweet and a little sour. I end up adding more vinegar than the recipe calls for to achieve a pucker that offsets all the other flavors perfectly. I do end up using about three times as much beets as potato because that's the star for me. I've served it without sour cream and loved it just as much. My husband talks unconsciously about how delicious it is while spooning more in his mouth, which tells me he really loves it :-)

really awesome, loved it. we will definitely make it again. my only complaint is there wasn't enough of it haha. i would double it next time as one batch was about 4 servings for us. i used one yellow potato, one medium beet, one medium onion, probably 3 tbsp butter, crushed tomatoes (instead of tomato puree), omitted the salt, and used 1/8 tsp dried dill.
I'm glad I gave this a try - It was delicious! I served it with Greek yogurt and sour cream. I never used dill in Borscht before, and am pleasantly surprised.

I read over this recipe and it's ok.  I just posted a recipe for borscht on my website (www.revivingtraditions.com/russian-borscht) and it’s amazing how different borscht recipes can be. I think EVERYBODY’s borcht recipe is different. In fact, my borscht from week to week might even taste different! Borscht just has that reputation. Cheers from a true Russian.
My husband I loved this soup. I left-out the tomatoes and tomato puree cause I dislike tomato in my Borscht and added more fresh dill and less salt and it was just perfect to us.

Being Russian myself I have a courage to say this is a great borscht recipe with Russian flavor. Believe me. Remember the main thing: there is not the one authentic borscht recipe, every single family make this dish on its own way. There are thousand variations and interpretations of this dish. We have the main ingredients - beets, cabbage (not exactly red, you can easily use a regular white cabbage), potatoes, carrots and onions. And then use your imagination. Some people make borscht using pork or beef, some add mushrooms, I`ve heard of even adding prunes. As to this recipe I would change the proportions a little just for my taste. I would use 1 1/2 cups beets, only one large onion and less tomato puree (tomatoes are optional but the borscht will be tastier). Don`t substitute cumin for caraway seeds. Cumin has an oriental flavor that can ruin Russian flavor in borscht. If you don`t have caraway seeds just omit them, they are optional. And definitely serve the borscht with sour cream, very traditional. The borscht consistency ends on your personal preference, if you prefer thick, add less water or more vegetables, if you prefer watery, add more water. So if you want to try Russian borscht, this is a great recipe to start.

I have made this quite a few times now and absolutely love it. I do tend to add more veggies than it calls for (2 carrots, extra beets, more cabbage) and throw in another 2 cups of stock. I wish I had a HUGE skillet to make an even bigger batch. To me, the caraway seeds are NOT optional. I have no knowledge of authentic borscht, but this tastes wonderful. It's a mainstay at our house, especially in the winter! We sometimes add pork to it as well.

It was great! I made it almost exactly like it said and loved it. The only thing I changed was that I used 2.5 big tbsp of tomato paste at the end instead of the tomato puree. Very much like my Mennonite Grandma used to make.

Learned a borscht trick at a Russian restaurant in Castlegar, BC. Sauté the onions, add chopped potatoes and beets; simmer till tender. Purée! Now return to pot and add rest of ingredients. Delicious thicker, hearty borscht.

This Summer we were in St. Petersburg Russia to attend a Wedding so I was anxious to try making my own Borscht. This is very good but what we had there was more earthy.I believe they must have used beef broth also and shredded the beets.Which I may try next time. Our household liked this very much as written and will add to our soup Sunday list.

This soup was easy to put together once you got everything chopped up. I used beef broth instead of vegetable (and had to put in an extra too cups because there wasn't enough liquid). My only complaint was that it was a bit too salty for my taste ... I would definitely omit the salt and just add it to taste at the end. Or maybe replace some of the broth with water.
Excellent recipe! Thank you for sharing it :) I thought it was perfect when I followed the recipe. Nice to see older recipes being shared and not lost.
really delicious! i was surprised how flavourful this was without any meat flavouring at all. yum! definitely a keeper.
Took way longer to prep than stated. Tasted very much like a sour ketchup chili. Would not make this again and think they're better recipes elsewhere

I made some changes for convenience and it turned out delicious! My first time making my favourite soup and this is a keeper! I added more beet (1 beet gave me 1 cup slices, so I used 2)I also added an extra stalk of celery and an extra carrot just for more veggies. Instead of red cabbage I used a bag of coleslaw mix (green cabbage with carrots)Didn't have cider vinegar so I did without it altogether. Also didn't have caraway seeds so I used cumin, though I only used 3/4 of a tsp because I was a bit nervous it would overpower, but it was fine! Had a package of fresh dill and added pretty much the whole thing. For the broth I used Organic PC vegetable stock. VERY YUMMY!
So incredibly beautiful. Thank you so much! I really love and appreciate this recipe. Thank you!!!
This is traditional peasant food so it's going to have dozens of variations. And spellings.
This soup is amazing! Better than I'd ever expected. I made it exactly as the recipe called for.

Oh my goodness. This is so delicious and filling. I absolutely love it. I am fasting from meat for 21 days and this borscht is so satisfying. I had some parsnips and turnips that I needed to use up so I also threw those in there. This is definitely a keeper authentic or not.
Made exactly to recipe with the optional caraway seeds. Wow! Great recipe!
Was amazing! Followed the recipe until the end...did not add chopped tomatoes. Was delicious and I will definitely be making it again.
Added a little extra garlic, but then again we do that for most soups. Fabulous!
